sections.title: Started from the bottom
sections.content: My first encounter with software development was at 13 years old. In 2016, I signed up for a youth robotics tournament, in which my team and I won first place (...for 3 years in a row). After my success, I got really interested in programming. I enrolled in a prestigious coding academy for young people in my town soon after, although I was by far the youngest person to ever attend that course. I learned what programming is, and how to make my first website. It was the starting point of my career.

sections.title: Hard work pays off
sections.content: Spending a few years learning is nothing to ignore, and as I found out, practicing programming at home in your free time really pays off. During this time, I had to decide which area to specialize in: frontend, backend, mobile... It was hard to decide, so I naturally tried everything. Nowadays I consider myself a full stack developer, capable of making web, desktop, and mobile applications, as well as backend servers, CLI tools, and games in multiple languages. It wasn't easy, mind you. I was going to high school at the same time and I was also competing in multiple tournaments organized by my school (in which our team, of course, won multiple times in a row again).

sections.title: The snowball effect
sections.content: It was 2022. School was ending, and I really had to get serious about my future career. I was still very cautious when looking for jobs or education opportunities, because I was unsure what I was getting myself into. Thankfully, I didn't have to fret too much about that, because I got offered a summer internship! This was a great opportunity for me, and I learned a lot. In fact, I even got a job offer at the same company, which was quite a new experience to me. I was still looking to improve my knowledge and to get formally educated, so unfortunately I had to decline the job offer in favor of going to university. What follows after, I am yet to find out.

techStack.name: Web

items.name: Javascript

items.description: This is the flavor of JS I use most of the time.

items.description: My go-to library for building websites.

items.name: Angular
items.description: Perfect for making large scale SPAs. I enjoy using it.

items.name: CSS
items.description: I rarely use CSS frameworks, but these come in handy.

items.name: Material Design
items.description: This technically has nothing to do with CSS, but it's my favorite design spec.

items.name: Backend

items.name: NestJS

items.name: KoaJS

items.name: Python
items.description: I rarely use Python for web development, but when I do, I use these.

items.description: I'm still experimenting with it, but I love me a good batteries-included framework.

items.name: Java
items.description: For very big backends.

items.name: SQL
items.description: Good ol' SQL. Although I rarely ever write it directly.

items.name: MySQL/MariaDB
items.description: My default database of choice.

items.name: MongoDB

techStack.name: Mobile
